Add assert statements to getData() and getTaskData() methods
commitResults.messageBody:
The program will run without errors
even if the output of CustomDateTime.getData() and Task.getTaskData() could not correctly initialize the same task.

This could cause saved data to be
corrupted without the user noticing.

Adding assert statements allow us to verify
the correctness of these methods and notify
the developer if any issue occurs.

Assert statements are used instead of
exceptions as the method's output should
be correct regardless of user input.

commitResults.messageTitle: Improve code quality
commitResults.messageBody:
Program included complicated expressions
and dead code in various places.
The 'happy path' was not obvious in some
methods.

These issues affected the readability of
the code by unfamiliar developers.

Simplified expressions with intermediate
values and removed dead code.
Changed logic flow of various methods such
that the 'happy path' was less nested.

commitResults.messageTitle: Merge pull request #1 from yoyongxuan/branch-A-Assertions
Merge branch 'master' into branch-A-CodeQuality
Merge pull request #2 from yoyongxuan/branch-A-CodeQuality
Change CustomDateTime to have a default date and time
commitResults.messageBody:
Uses 2359 if date is provided but not time.
Uses current date if time is provided but not date.
Does not use any default if neither date
 nor time are provided.

commitResults.messageTitle: Update task constructor methods to no longer throw InvalidInputException
commitResults.messageBody:
Since the behaviour of CustomDateTime was
 changed to no longer throw an exception,
 exceptions will no longer be raised in
 the constructor methods of DeadlineTask
 and EventTask.
 Thus, update task constructors and
 various methods calling said constructors.

commitResults.messageTitle: Add recurring tasks for deadline and event tasks
commitResults.messageBody:
Many tasks occur periodically and users have to
add multiple similar tasks to the list to track them.

This is tedious for the user and results in a
messy and cluttered task list.

Users now have the ability to set recurring
tasks which replace themselves with a
similar task a set number of days later once it
has been marked as done.

This allows users to track the next instance of
the task at all times without filling the task
list with multiple copies of similar tasks.
